reasoning: The LSTM layer expects a 3D input (batch_size, timesteps, features). The current train_data shape is (num_samples, SIZE, SIZE), which is 3D, but the LSTM layer is being initialized with input_shape=(train_data.shape[1], train_data.shape[2]), which is (SIZE, SIZE). This means the LSTM layer is expecting a 2D input for each timestep, but the data is structured such that each 'timestep' is a row of pixels, and the 'features' are individual pixels. This is a common mismatch when trying to feed image data directly into an LSTM without proper reshaping or flattening of the image features per timestep. The error will likely occur during model.fit when the input shape doesn't match the expected input of the LSTM layer.
The LSTM layer expects a 3D input (batch_size, timesteps, features). The current train_data shape is (num_samples, 1, 224, 224), which is 4D. This will cause a ValueError when creating the model.
